body:
The problem is with client window mode is that the view's clientid is used as a key to store the render map and execute map tokens. 

See https://github.com/apache/myfaces/blob/6ee216abb06a790c2dbd9012c4400756014f7323/impl/src/main/java/org/apache/myfaces/context/flash/FlashImpl.java#L769

With url mode enabled, a refresh of the page generates a new id and then the previous maps can't be found. Hence, the values in the flash map aren't displayed. Url mode works fine if you got to a different page (unless you use the disableClientWindow in the tag).

My code was for the scenario where url mode was enabled by default (not via user), but I think you're that that I should update it to check for the URL mode specifically.

We should have some clean up / follow up perhaps later on? I don't understand why we have `org.apache.myfaces.DEFAULT_WINDOW_MODE` (default url) and `jakarta.faces.CLIENT_WINDOW_MODE` (default none)

https://github.com/apache/myfaces/blob/89c747e85615e3f33265e664c8361789f38ea7db/impl/src/main/java/org/apache/myfaces/lifecycle/clientwindow/ClientWindowFactoryImpl.java#L37
Yeah, seems so

At the same time, if we use cookies if url mode is enabled by the user then why not just remove the client window checks here? Cookies would be used every time then. (As in JSF 2.0).  I think I'll just document the limitation in the JIRA issue. This problem only occurs if the flash is set on a page which is refreshed.  I see most online discussions about flash regarding different views / redirects. 


I think I'd prefer to leave the PR as is, but we could revisit later on if needed.

We could problem clean this up a bit by creating a method and thus reducing some of the similar code. This could be followed up on at a later time. 

Merging.

i think we need to dig a bit deeper
i understand your problem as URL ClientWindow doesnt do something like a initialRedirect, so when you visit the view and press f5, the clientWindow is will be regenerated

AFAICS Mojarra doesnt even use the ClientWindow for flash stuff
why did MyFaces introduce this?

Yes, I saw Mojarra used cookies for flash too (at least for the scenario in the TCK). No idea why MyFaces changed. 

I see some mention here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MYFACES-3404 (`Add windowId to server side state saving algorithm`) 

```
 There are two points where this logic could be useful inside MyFaces Core :

1. Server side state
2. Flash scope

But in practice the only really relevant is 1. To implement 2. it is necessary
a "requestId". MyFaces FlashImpl uses a counter and store its value inside
a cookie. To fix this scope properly, the best is create a ExternalContext
wrapper and provide and alternate Flash object, but that sounds like something
that can be done outside MyFaces Core. If you are using CDI scopes, it sounds
reasonable to provide an alternate Flash scope in CODI.
```

@tandraschko @melloware  The build for the checks in this PR looks to have run fine, but I got a notification about another build(?) here: https://github.com/apache/myfaces/actions/runs/3894271347/jobs/6648712819
 
 It failed due to: 
```
  Error:  Errors: 
Error:    IntegrationTest.test » DroneTimeout Drone creation request timed out after 60 seconds. Make sure that browser or remote server in case of remotely executed driver is running and communication with Drone haven't failed.
Error:    IntegrationTest.testPlainHtml » DroneTimeout Drone creation request timed out after 60 seconds. Make sure that browser or remote server in case of remotely executed driver is running and communication with Drone haven't failed.

 Error:  Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-surefire-plugin:3.0.0-M7:test (default) on project faceletToXhtmlMapping:
```

Any concerns here?
Hmmm definitely looks like the Integration tests got stuck or something?
@tandraschko Would you prefer to use flash cookies altogether and move away from client window logic?

I would do the following:
1) change your IF to "isUrlMode", also when the user sets it
2) please add a comment and link to the issue number

@bohmber it looks like the IT tests just started failing with this error..

" IntegrationTest.test » Runtime Unable to instantiate Drone via org.openqa.selenium.chrome.ChromeDriver(Capabilities): org.openqa.selenium.SessionNotCreatedException: session not created: This version of ChromeDriver only supports Chrome version 109"
@melloware looks like with new Chrome version there is a problem with the IT test

chromedriver version 109.0.5414.25 contains two files now.  

`chromedriver             
 LICENSE.chromedriver`

that is the reason why the IT test are failing on my local

Guys have a look at the chrome manager library https://github.com/bonigarcia/webdrivermanager
this takes care of choosing and loading the proper chrome driver!
@werpu That is what I use in all my projects!  but not sure what Arquillian Drone does....

I have had a look at it quickly for my tck ports, I decided back then against it, because I needed to extend the webdriver and the test setup already was present, hence. I used webdriver manager which gave me low level access. Afair it is a meta layer on top of arquillian which simplifies and automates things.
Probably worthwhile to explore in a totally setup or if you dont have anything and need to get started!

https://arquillian.org/arquillian-extension-drone/
#arquillian/arquillian-extension-drone/pull/373
@bohmber FYI I've just released Drone 3.0.0-alpha.7 with the fix for this very issue. It's already available in official JBoss Repository and should be synced with Maven Central shortly.
@bartoszmajsak thanks a lot
Need to run this against the TCK  before merging.  Also, the TCK needs to increase the jakarta.faces.FACELETS_BUFFER_SIZE param since we commit the response before the exception.
Just an FYI Mojarra had a similar recent issue about not respecting FACELETS_BUFFER_SIZE.  https://github.com/eclipse-ee4j/mojarra/issues/5164

Actually this is a exception which already fails in development mode
I would not increase the buffer size in general for this

What do you mean? An exception is thrown in our code already if the project is set to development mode? I tested this, but still received a 200 response? Here's the output: The application would need to increase it's buffer size, since it commits the response and then just appends the exception. The TCK expects a 500. Unless you think the test needs to be updated?
thank you!
I would like to see this merged
the indentations are looking bit weird/to small? otherwise +1
@tandraschko i thought we had checkstyle on this project?  Shouldn't it catch indention issues?
yep but IMO the myfaces checkstyle is not configured hard enough
closing it... a pr is not what is needed for further work on this
Not a fan of the formatting either, but I get check style exceptions if the bracket's aren't on a new line.
Indented some of the nested statements / blocks so it should look better.  Will merge once the CI build completes.
i think we should also only check this if projecstage == development
@melloware if you merge PRs, please always update the JIRA issues

We would need to address that via a TCK challenge since Mojarra checks it by default. 

But I agree that that this check makes sense during development, not production.
Yep will do.

Only documentation I know of: https://myfaces.apache.org/#/core40

https://github.com/apache/myfaces-homepage/blob/main/core40.md
Thank you I updated that MD to have the default be `false`
I can submit for 2.3-next.

@melloware @tandraschko  

Challenge hasn't had any movement -- I'd like to merge this PR for now for RC4 and we can switch this check to development depending on throw the challenge is resolved.
that sounds good to me we have future RC's if we need to change anything.
Same as before good with me.  we can always fix in RC5 :)

I would just change it to dev mode only, it doesnt make sense in production
We can still revert it If require or skip this test
I will review tomorrow

Do not merge this in util the server side implementation is fixed to be able to deal with namespaces.
You can use it as a base for the namespace tck though
As i said, i would skip the whole checks on dev stage
closing it for now
Reopened after fixing a last minute issue
LGTM
Added check for development stage -- merging
Need to check one more edge case before merging

This code addresses the issue found in the TCK, but it fails in our tests. You can find the failures in the build log, for example: 
```
Error:  Tests run: 5, Failures: 2, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 2.055 s <<< FAILURE! - in org.apache.myfaces.application.flow.FlowMyFacesCDIRequestTestCase
Error:  org.apache.myfaces.application.flow.FlowMyFacesCDIRequestTestCase.testFlow1_1  Time elapsed: 0.369 s  <<< FAILURE!
java.lang.AssertionError: 
expected null, but was:<<navigation-case>
  <from-view-id>/flow1_1.xhtml</from-view-id>
  <from-outcome>content</from-outcome>
  <to-view-id>/flow1/content.xhtml</to-view-id>
</navigation-case>>
	at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:89)
	at org.junit.Assert.failNotNull(Assert.java:756)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertNull(Assert.java:738)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertNull(Assert.java:748)
	at org.apache.myfaces.application.flow.FlowMyFacesCDIRequestTestCase.testFlow1_1(FlowMyFacesCDIRequestTestCase.java:72)
```

https://github.com/apache/myfaces/blob/93a47f3c78716f0ff3c01227ee1cd5972aeb965b/impl/src/test/java/org/apache/myfaces/application/flow/FlowMyFacesCDIRequestTestCase.java#L59-L72

@werpu sorry asked you to weigh in on a similar issue i think you ran into with HTMLUnit OmniFaces IT tests are wonky with MyFaces 4 but i think its HTMLUnit related.  See: https://github.com/omnifaces/omnifaces/issues/729
Challenge was accepted, so I'll close this PR.
Last commit update -- Empty string / null means there is no value -- do not convert them for ui select one.
All checks passed -- merging.

```
Error:  Failures: 
Error:    FlowMyFacesRequestTestCase.testFlow1_10:940 expected:<flow[3]> but was:<flow[1]>
Error:    FlowMyFacesRequestTestCase.testFlow1_10_1:1028 expected:<flow[3]> but was:<flow[1]>
Error:    FlowMyFacesRequestTestCase.testFlow1_10_2:1116 expected:<flow[3]> but was:<flow[1]>
Error:    FlowMyFacesRequestTestCase.testFlow1_8:684 expected:<flow[3]> but was:<flow[1]>
```

Made a update and it's down to 4 failures now. However, I don't really like this approach, but I don't see much we can do. We follow the spec (mostly), but I think Mojarra just made more updates made to address edge cases and the spec was never updated.

Basically, when should a flow be entered so that flowScope is active?
I wonder if this is a question for BalusC?
Please see my jira comment, doesnt make sense IMO

Answered... yes it very likely is a similar isse, the code affected probably uses valid Ecmascript constructs, which Rhino simply cannot handle anymore! Rhino being stuck in the stoneage also was the reason why Oracle a few years ago dropped it as JS engine in the JDK, and moved to Nashorn!

GREEN GREEN GREEN!  💚   Never been so happy to see a "BUILD SUCCESSFUL". 

Still need do some more testing and refactor the changes a bit (as well as comment the code), but I think I've fixed this without causing any regressions.
Congratulations!!  I know you have been fighting this one!

I left this todo in as point of discussion, see also my last comment on MyFaces 4533!
I will fix it as soon as everyone is ok with a strategy on how we optimize it!
This is not ready for merge yet, I will merge probably tomorrow!

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MYFACES-4533  last comment, last section. I need further input here.
The code yet is unoptomized, but I guess we can store the parameters determined there in the faces context attributes or somewhere else which is request scoped for speed improvement, hence the TODO!

Btw. I already have prepared fixes for master, 2.3-next and 2.3 is still in work, so once we merge this code in, expect a fix for master relatively quickly, 2.3-next and 2.3 need some additional testing!
Nice work!  I appreciated the persistence!

TBH im not sure if we should backport it to older branches
viewroot namespacing is only used in portlets and no portlet impl uses myfaces
so this is only for be TCK compatible and will never be used in production for now

also we must optimize the server side stuff
always a new object instance (ParamsNamingContainerResolver) and so on isnt quite good for a feature which isnt used
I think @tandraschko already made this fix in 4.0?
Oops looks like it was already fixed yesterday :) Closing - need to remember to pull beforehand

I can live with not porting it to the older implementations, but for the sanity of keeping the javascript implementations together I need to have this functionality on the client side enabled since they are mostly in sync now over all branches (with 2.3 having a ton of ie fixes in, but that part is mostly isolated in separate shim classes). 
I have full ports for 2.3 and 2.3-next lingering in my codebase!

I also took the TODO out for now, given it is only a speed hit for the portlet case and probably minimal, we still can optimize it later by caching the result.
Once the test is fixed and everyone agrees I will start to merge into 4.0 and my pull request!
As for the old implementations, lets discuss this after the first major merges!
I will issue pull requests as I already have prepared them for 2.3 and 2.3-next and we then can discuss them!


--
Will check the failing test now...
The standard unit tests all pass result of the TCK tests please see the MYFACES-4533 issue!

Ok the issue seems to be deeper, this will take a while, I also can reproduce it on my private integration tests.

-- seems the tests only fall on the old codebase
all branches now have more or less the same server side impl, will run compares, but it its likely that the js files cause the issue the ts files work

The problem is indeed in the scripts, some expected params like the source got lost along the way in the old scripts.
Thanks to whoever wrote this test!

Fix comitted, also my 21 local ajax tests have passed now: Spec 790 passes as well: Also the tcks pass as well as before on 2.2 level: the failing test is a server side problem and reported! In other words, we theoretically could merge this now into main!

Thank you for all your hard work on this.  Glad to see it's finally passing. I think we should be at 100% for the TCK with this change now :) 

As for the PR, it looks like it could be rebased since it contains older commits? 

I also created this small commit for caching the prefix if you wanted to use it: https://github.com/apache/myfaces/commit/5309b7c7059f078636b0f2e8b7ddacded402f181

It should keep things in the current faces context until it's released. 

https://jakarta.ee/specifications/faces/4.0/apidocs/jakarta/faces/context/facescontext#getAttributes()

not sure 100% see the failing Issue3833IT 2.2 test regarding the ui repeat and savestates (image above), which is clearly a bug on the implementation side. 
Also note I only run the Ajax related tests, so other non Ajax related TCKs still might be failing!

I will add it the prefix caching and merge afterwards.
So I guess we finally can merge this now at least for master and the pull request!

I will open a discussion for the rest of the branches afterwards! I would love to at least see the fixes
in the javascripts to keep them in sync, otherwise I will have a maintenance nightmare on my head!

Added the caching!
Tests still pass, TCK as well!

TBH i dont like the way how ParamsNamingContainerResolver works
this breaks external libs like PrimeFaces

i think e.g. context.getExternalContext().getRequestParameterMap() should be do all the work internally

if you need help to implement this, i can do it for you
please just rebase the PR here and with only JS changes
and provide a second PR with server side changes, so i can take a look in detail

@tandraschko 
Thanks for the suggestion, does it really break the external libs? 

Lets see what you come up with it. I thought about adding the functionality to the parameter map as well, but omitted the idea because i thought it was too central and would affect third party libs...
Call me interested!

https://github.com/apache/myfaces/pull/510 
Pull request opened @tandraschko feel free to take over!

AFAIR all params are prefixed, thats how we implemented it with liferay team: https://github.com/primefaces/primefaces/blob/master/primefaces/src/main/resources/META-INF/resources/primefaces/core/core.ajax.js#L607

Yes thats more or less what the current js code does now!
Per spec the sent params now are prefixed with the naming container id in the naming container case!

perfect
the TCK just adds a overwritten viewRoot in the testproject then?

Yes thats pretty much where it fails, the failing Spec790 test issues an implicit ajax navgiation over an action outcome, the root cause simply is that the impl fails to detect the jakarta.faces.ViewState and other parameters properly because internally they were not prefixed, and thats pretty much all my fix and the code I got from @volosied I was basing my fix on, was about!

@werpu @tandraschko 

I know Spec790 has has taken lot of our time. I suppose Thomas could try to find a solution for the java code side of it (would be great if you could), but, if not, we could challenge it instead?

yeah
let me check it today or tomorrow

in theory its only a porlet feature, not really required by JSF TCK
Yes closed is fine  this will be handled by the associated pull requests regarding TCK 790!
containsKey uses getAttribute, see AbstractAttributeMap

I will run the tests tomorrow, but the HTMLResponseStateManager definitiely still needs some of the fixes I mentioned, because it is responsible for rendering the prefixed names!
The ugly thing is, while we have an api which determines the NamingContainer name, there are some phase where it is not present yet (hence the hack with the parameter lookup) and to the worse it might change later in a navigational case (if possible)

i will commit the writing part now
if the TCK is green, i'm fine with the current changes
everything else should be in the porlet adapter code then - the viewroot will be never a namingcontainer is a normal container

Yes if the TCk passes then we are set
